How to Cite YouTube Videos in MLA 9 Format

How to cite YouTube videos in MLA 9 format

Need APA format instead? View APA 7 version ‚Üí

üìã Quick Reference

Author Last, First Name. Title of Work. Publisher, Year.

Tip: Copy this template and replace with your source details.

üîç Try It Out

Paste a youtube citation to check your formatting

What an MLA 9 YouTube citation needs to do

In MLA 9, a Works Cited entry should help a reader quickly identify the exact video you used and find it again. YouTube videos can change titles, be reuploaded, or be removed, so your citation needs clear details like the video title, the uploader or creator, the website name, the date, and the URL.

MLA 9 is flexible about containers and contributors, but it is strict about clarity and consistency. That is why the order and formatting of elements matters. A correct YouTube citation:

  • Gives credit to the creator or uploader.
  • Identifies the specific video, not just the channel.
  • Provides a stable path to the source, usually the direct URL.
  • Uses consistent punctuation and formatting, which makes your Works Cited easy to scan and alphabetize.

Core MLA 9 format for a YouTube video

Standard Works Cited template

Author or Creator. ‚ÄúTitle of Video.‚Äù YouTube, uploaded by Channel Name (if different from author), Day Month Year, URL.

Not every video has every element. MLA lets you include what is useful and available, but you should keep the standard order.

What each part means

  • Author or Creator: The person primarily responsible for the content. If a real person is credited, use that person. If the video is primarily branded by an organization, you can treat the organization as the author.
  • ‚ÄúTitle of Video.‚Äù: Put the video title in quotation marks because it is a work within a larger website.
  • YouTube: This is the website, and it is italicized as the container.
  • uploaded by Channel Name: Use this only when it clarifies responsibility, for example when the creator is a person, but the channel name is different, or when an organization uploads a person‚Äôs talk. If the author and channel are the same, you can omit ‚Äúuploaded by.‚Äù
  • Day Month Year: Use the publication date shown on YouTube. MLA prefers day first, then month spelled out, then year.
  • URL: Use the direct link to the video. MLA does not require ‚Äúhttps://‚Äù but it is acceptable to include it. Be consistent.

Author rules you must follow for this guide

Your rules change how you handle names, especially compared with many quick MLA examples online. Follow these exactly.

Full first names, not initials

Use full first names whenever possible. This improves clarity and avoids confusion between people with similar initials. It also respects the creator‚Äôs identity by not reducing the name to initials.

  • Correct: Nguyen, Minh Anh.
  • Avoid: Nguyen, M. A.

If YouTube only provides a channel handle and you cannot reliably find the full name, treat it as no author and begin with the title. Do not invent a full name.

First author must be inverted

The first author in a Works Cited entry must be inverted for alphabetizing.

  • Correct: Last, First Middle.
  • Example: Smith, Jordan Lee.

Two authors use ‚Äúand,‚Äù second name not inverted

If two creators are credited as authors, invert only the first name.

  • Correct: Garcia, Elena Maria, and Thomas David Reed.
  • Incorrect: Garcia, Elena Maria, and Reed, Thomas David.

Three or more authors use ‚Äúet al.‚Äù after the first author only

List only the first author, inverted, then add et al. This keeps entries readable and consistent.

  • Correct: Patel, Anika Rani, et al.
  • Incorrect: Patel, Anika Rani, Jordan Lee Smith, and Mei Chen.

No author, start with the title

If no author can be identified, begin with the title in quotation marks. For alphabetizing, ignore A, An, and The.

  • Correct: ‚ÄúHow to Calibrate a Telescope.‚Äù
  • Avoid: Starting with ‚ÄúAnonymous‚Äù or using ‚Äún.d.‚Äù

Example 1, single author who matches the channel name

Works Cited entry

Nguyen, Minh Anh. ‚ÄúHow to Write a Strong Thesis Statement.‚Äù YouTube, 14 Mar. 2023, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XXXXXXXXXXX.

Why it is formatted this way

  • Nguyen, Minh Anh is inverted because it is the first author element in the entry.
  • The video title is in quotation marks because it is a short work inside a larger container, YouTube.
  • YouTube is italicized because it is the container.
  • The date is written in MLA style, day month year, with the month abbreviated.
  • The URL points directly to the video, which is what your reader needs to verify your evidence.

Practical tip

Copy the video title exactly as it appears, including capitalization and punctuation, but do not copy extra labels like ‚ÄúOfficial Video‚Äù unless it is part of the title.

Example 2, author is a person, uploader is a different channel

This situation is common for interviews, conference talks, or guest lectures, where the speaker is not the channel owner.

Works Cited entry

Okafor, Chinedu Michael. ‚ÄúUrban Planning Basics, Zoning and Walkability.‚Äù YouTube, uploaded by CityLab Learning, 2 Sept. 2022, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YYYYYYYYYYY.

Why it is formatted this way

  • Okafor, Chinedu Michael is treated as the author because he is the primary creator of the content, the speaker.
  • uploaded by CityLab Learning is included because it helps the reader locate the video and clarifies that the channel is not the same as the author.
  • The rest follows the same MLA order: title, container, uploader, date, URL.

Common pitfall

Do not invert the uploader name after ‚Äúuploaded by.‚Äù In MLA, ‚Äúuploaded by‚Äù is a descriptive phrase, not the lead author element. Keep it in normal order as shown on YouTube.

Example 3, no identifiable author, begin with the title

If the video is posted by a channel name that does not clearly identify a person, and you cannot confirm a full personal name, you should treat it as no author under your rules.

Works Cited entry

‚ÄúBeginner Guitar Lesson, First Five Chords.‚Äù YouTube, 8 Jan. 2021, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZZZZZZZZZZZ.

Why it is formatted this way

  • You start with the title because there is no reliable author name you can present in full first name form.
  • You still include YouTube, the date, and the URL so the reader can locate the exact video.
  • For alphabetizing in Works Cited, you would alphabetize by Beginner, and you would ignore A, An, or The if the title started with those words.

Practical tip

If the channel is clearly an organization with a formal name, you can use that organization as the author. For example, ‚ÄúNational Park Service‚Äù can be an author. A handle like ‚Äú@guitarpro247‚Äù usually should not be treated as a personal author unless you can confirm the creator‚Äôs real full name.

Why these rules matter

They make your Works Cited easy to alphabetize and scan

Inverting the first author name supports consistent alphabetical order. Using full first names reduces confusion, especially when multiple creators share a last name like Smith, Lee, or Garcia.

They strengthen credibility

Precise citations show that you are careful with sources. That matters in academic writing, especially when using media that can be edited, deleted, or reposted.

They help readers verify your evidence

A YouTube citation is not just about giving credit. It is also about letting your reader check context, tone, and exact wording. The direct URL and correct title are essential.

Practical tips for citing YouTube videos in MLA 9

  • Use the video‚Äôs publication date, not the date you watched it, unless your instructor specifically asks for an access date. MLA usually does not require access dates for stable sources, but YouTube can change. If you include an access date, add it at the end, for example: Accessed 31 Dec. 2025.
  • Keep titles in quotation marks, not italics, because the video is a part of YouTube.
  • Do not cite the channel handle as a person‚Äôs name. If you cannot identify a full first name, treat it as no author and start with the title.
  • Use ‚Äúuploaded by‚Äù only when it adds clarity. If the author and channel are the same, leaving it out avoids repetition.
  • Check punctuation carefully. MLA relies on periods to separate core parts. A missing period can make entries harder to read.

Common pitfalls to avoid

  • Using initials for the author when a full first name is available. Your guide requires full first names.
  • Inverting the second author in a two author entry. Only the first author is inverted.
  • Listing all authors for three or more creators instead of using et al. after the first author.
  • Starting with ‚ÄúAnonymous‚Äù or using ‚Äún.d.‚Äù MLA does not require that, and your rules forbid it.
  • Linking to a channel page instead of the specific video. Always use the direct video URL.

Quick checklist before you submit

  • Did you invert the first author name, and use full first names?
  • If there are two authors, did you use ‚Äúand‚Äù and keep the second name in normal order?
  • If there are three or more authors, did you use et al. after the first author only?
  • If there is no author, did you begin with the title in quotation marks?
  • Did you italicize YouTube and include the date and direct URL?

If you share one of your YouTube sources, including the link and the creator or channel name, I can format it in this exact style and explain any tricky parts.

Step-by-Step Instructions

Common Errors for Youtube Citations

‚ú® Ready to Check Your Full Reference List?

Validate your entire bibliography at once with our citation checker

Validation Checklist

Before submitting your Youtube citation, verify:

  • Author names MUST use full first names, not initials. In MLA 9, the emphasis is on full names to provide clarity and respect for the author's identity. The first author's name is inverted (Last, First Middle), while subsequent authors in two-author works use normal order (First Last).
  • First author name MUST be inverted (Last, First Middle). This applies to all source types and is the standard opening format for MLA citations. The inversion facilitates alphabetical ordering in the Works Cited list.
  • For TWO authors: use 'and' between names (second name NOT inverted). The word 'and' is preferred in MLA for its formality and readability.
  • For THREE OR MORE authors: use 'et al.' after first author only. Do not list additional authors before 'et al.' This simplifies lengthy author lists while maintaining proper attribution. The first author must still use full first name, not initials.
  • NO AUTHOR: Start with title (ignore 'A', 'An', 'The' for alphabetization). Do not use 'n.d.' or 'Anonymous'. The title becomes the first element and should maintain proper formatting (quotes for short works, italics for complete works).
  • ALL titles MUST use Title Case (capitalize all major words). This includes articles, books, websites, and all other sources. Title Case means capitalizing the first and last words, and all principal words (nouns, pronouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs). Articles (a, an, the), coordinating conjunctions, and prepositions are lowercase unless first or last word.
  • Shorter works use QUOTATION MARKS: Article titles, chapter titles, web page titles, poems, short stories, episodes. These are works that are part of a larger container. Quotation marks indicate the work is not standalone.
  • Complete works use ITALICS: Book titles, journal names, website names, films, TV series. These are standalone, self-contained works that serve as containers for shorter works. Italics indicate independence and completeness.
  • Do NOT use both italics AND quotation marks on same title. This is redundant and incorrect. Choose one based on whether the work is shorter (quotes) or complete (italics).
  • Date placement: AFTER publisher, BEFORE page numbers/URL. The date follows the publisher in the publication sequence.

Special Cases

Overview, what makes YouTube citations tricky in MLA 9

YouTube looks simple at first, but it creates many edge cases because the platform mixes several roles and labels. A person can be the creator, the on screen speaker, the uploader, and the channel owner. The title can change over time, the URL can be long, and videos may be reposted or clipped by someone else. MLA 9 is flexible, but you still need consistent choices so your reader can find the exact video you used.

A standard MLA 9 Works Cited entry for a YouTube video often follows this pattern:

Creator or uploader. ‚ÄúTitle of Video.‚Äù YouTube, uploaded by Uploader (if different), Day Month Year, URL.

Your special rules about author names still apply. Use full first names, not initials. Invert the first author name. For two authors, use ‚Äúand‚Äù with the second name not inverted. For three or more, use the first author then ‚Äúet al.‚Äù If there is no author, start with the title.

Special case 1, creator name versus channel name versus uploader

When a real person is clearly responsible

If the video is clearly created by a person and the channel is that person‚Äôs official channel, you can usually treat that person as the author. Use the name exactly as it appears publicly, but expand initials when you know the full first name. This matters because MLA emphasizes who is responsible for the work, and a person‚Äôs name is more informative than a brand label.

Practical tip: If the channel name is a nickname, but the About page or video description gives the full name, use the full name in the citation. If you cannot confirm the full first name, you should not guess. In that case, use the channel name as written.

When a channel or organization is the author

If the uploader is an organization, a newsroom, a university, or a company channel, treat the organization as the author. This is common for lectures, press briefings, and promotional content.

Common pitfall: Do not list both the organization and the same organization again as ‚Äúuploaded by.‚Äù Only include ‚Äúuploaded by‚Äù when it adds new information, meaning the uploader is different from the author.

Special case 2, ‚Äúuploaded by‚Äù is different from the creator

Reuploads are common. A fan account might upload a clip from a TV show. A conference attendee might upload a keynote recording. In MLA 9, you can cite the uploader as the author if the uploader is the only clear responsible party on YouTube, but you should also acknowledge the original creator when it is important for credibility.

A practical approach:
- If you are analyzing the YouTube upload itself, such as commentary, edits, captions, or a compilation, cite the uploader as the author.
- If you are using the video as evidence of the original creator‚Äôs work, you should try to cite the original source if available. If you must use YouTube, you can still cite the YouTube item, but be clear about the uploader and the context.

Why this matters: Readers need to know whether they are seeing an official publication or an unofficial repost, because that affects reliability and the ability to verify.

Special case 3, multiple authors or collaborators

YouTube videos often list multiple hosts, guests, or a production team. MLA does not require you to list everyone. Your rules apply:

  • Two authors: invert the first author only, use ‚Äúand‚Äù for the second author in normal order.
  • Three or more: list the first author then ‚Äúet al.‚Äù

Who counts as an author here? Usually the creator or the channel owner, not every guest speaker. Guests can be mentioned in your sentence or in a note if needed, but they typically do not belong in the author slot unless the video is explicitly presented as their work.

Common pitfall: Treating a guest interviewee as the author when the channel produced and published the video. If the channel created the video and the guest is just featured, the channel or creator is usually the author.

Special case 4, no author listed, or author is unclear

Sometimes a video has a generic channel name, no real name, and no clear organization. Under your rules, if there is no author, start with the title of the video in quotation marks.

Why this matters: MLA Works Cited entries are alphabetized. Starting with the title provides a stable way to locate the entry, and it avoids inventing an author.

Practical tip: Alphabetize by the first meaningful word in the title. Ignore A, An, and The.

Special case 5, titles with emojis, hashtags, or unusual capitalization

YouTube titles often include emojis, all caps, or hashtags. MLA prefers the title as it appears in the source, but you can make it readable.

Good practice:
- Keep the wording the same.
- You may omit emojis if they do not affect meaning, especially if they make the citation hard to read.
- Keep hashtags only if they are part of the title‚Äôs meaning.

Common pitfall: Changing the title to sentence case or ‚Äúfixing‚Äù it too much. Your goal is findability, not rewriting.

Special case 6, dates, premieres, and missing dates

YouTube usually shows a publication date. Use it in Day Month Year format, like 14 Feb. 2024. If the exact day is not visible, use whatever is available, but YouTube normally provides a full date.

Do not use ‚Äún.d.‚Äù under your rules. If no date is available, omit the date and move directly to the URL. This is rare on YouTube, but it can happen with older or unusual uploads.

Practical tip: Use the date shown on the video page, not the date you watched it. MLA 9 generally does not require an access date unless the content is likely to change or is hard to recover. YouTube videos can be removed, but the citation is still usually acceptable without an access date unless your instructor requires one.

Special case 7, time stamps in in-text citations

A key edge case for YouTube is pointing to a specific moment. MLA in-text citations can include a time range. This is not part of the Works Cited entry, it is part of the in-text citation.

Example format in text: (Author Last Name 2:15 to 2:42)

Why this matters: Videos are long. Time stamps let your reader verify the exact claim without searching.

Common pitfall: Putting the time stamp in the Works Cited entry. Keep it in the in-text citation instead.

Special case 8, shortened URLs, tracking links, and playlists

Use a clean, direct URL to the video. Avoid tracking parameters, and avoid links that route through playlists unless you are specifically citing the playlist.

Good practice:
- Use the full video URL from the address bar.
- Remove extra parameters after the video ID when possible.

Common pitfall: Citing a mobile share link with tracking text. It can break later, and it looks messy.

Examples with explanations (correct formatting)

Example 1, individual creator, channel matches creator

Works Cited entry
Carpenter, John Michael. ‚ÄúHow to Read a Poem in Three Steps.‚Äù YouTube, 14 Feb. 2024, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EXAMPLE12345.

Why it is formatted this way
- The author is a person, so the entry starts with the inverted name, Carpenter, John Michael. This supports alphabetizing and matches MLA norms.
- The title is in quotation marks because it is a work within a larger site.
- YouTube is italicized as the container.
- The date is included in Day Month Year format.
- The URL is direct and placed at the end for retrieval.

Common pitfall to avoid
Do not write ‚ÄúCarpenter, J. M.‚Äù because your rule requires full first names, not initials.

Example 2, two authors, co-created channel video

Works Cited entry
Nguyen, Elena Marie, and Marcus Reed. ‚ÄúBudget Cooking, Five Meals for Ten Dollars.‚Äù YouTube, 3 May 2023, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EXAMPLE67890.

Why it is formatted this way
- Two authors are listed. The first author is inverted, Nguyen, Elena Marie.
- The second author is not inverted, Marcus Reed, and ‚Äúand‚Äù connects them.
- This matters because it is consistent and readable, and it signals equal co-authorship without creating confusion in alphabetization.

In-text citation with a time stamp
(Nguyen and Reed 6:10 to 6:45)

Common pitfall to avoid
Do not invert the second author. Do not write ‚ÄúReed, Marcus‚Äù in the author slot for a two-author entry.

Example 3, no author, start with the title, organization is only in the channel name and unclear

Works Cited entry
‚ÄúUnderstanding Plate Tectonics for Beginners.‚Äù YouTube, 9 Sept. 2022, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EXAMPLE24680.

Why it is formatted this way
- There is no clear author name that can be verified as a person or organization, so the citation begins with the title.
- This follows your no author rule and avoids guessing.
- The entry still provides enough information for a reader to locate the video.

Common pitfall to avoid
Do not use ‚ÄúAnonymous‚Äù or ‚Äún.d.‚Äù If you cannot identify an author or date, omit what you cannot verify and rely on the title and URL.

Practical tips and common pitfalls checklist

  • Confirm the author carefully. Use a person‚Äôs full first name only when you can verify it. Do not guess.
  • Use ‚Äúuploaded by‚Äù only when it adds information. If the author and uploader are the same, do not repeat.
  • Keep titles findable. Do not rewrite titles heavily. Remove clutter only when it does not change meaning.
  • Clean your URL. Avoid tracking parameters and playlist links unless the playlist is what you are citing.
  • Use time stamps in in-text citations. Put 2:15 to 2:42 in parentheses in your paper, not in Works Cited.
  • Be consistent. Your reader should be able to scan your Works Cited and immediately see who made the content, what it is called, where it lives, and how to find it.

If you want, share one or two real YouTube links you are citing, and I can show the best MLA 9 Works Cited entry under your author name rules, including how to handle the channel name you see on the page.

Frequently Asked Questions

How do I cite a YouTube video in MLA 9 in my Works Cited?

In MLA 9, a YouTube video entry usually starts with the video title in quotation marks, then the site name (YouTube) in italics, the uploader or channel name, the upload date, and the URL. Add an access date only if your instructor requests it or if the content is likely to change. Practical example, if you are citing a documentary clip you watched for a media studies paper, your entry will look like: ‚ÄúTitle of Video.‚Äù YouTube, uploaded by Channel Name, Day Month Year, URL. If the uploader is the same as the author you would otherwise name, you can list it in the ‚Äúuploaded by‚Äù position rather than repeating it as the author. For official organizational channels, use the organization name as the uploader. For MLA‚Äôs guidance, see https://style.mla.org/ and for the MLA Handbook overview, https://www.mla.org/MLA-Style.

Do I cite the person in the video or the YouTube channel as the author?

Use the creator most responsible for the work you are citing. If the video is posted by the same person who created it, the channel or uploader functions as the author. If the video is from a channel that reposts content created by someone else, cite the uploader in the ‚Äúuploaded by‚Äù element, but you can also name the performer, speaker, or director in the description if it helps your reader. Practical scenario, you cite a TED talk hosted on YouTube. If the video is uploaded by the official TED channel, list the talk title first, then YouTube, then ‚Äúuploaded by TED,‚Äù plus the date and URL. In your prose you can still mention the speaker. For more detail on authorship and containers, consult MLA‚Äôs guidance on works cited entries at https://style.mla.org/works-cited-a-quick-guide/.

How do I cite a specific timestamp or quote from a YouTube video in an in-text citation?

MLA in-text citations usually use author and page number, but videos have no pages. When quoting or referring to a precise moment, include the author or title element you use in your Works Cited, plus a timestamp in the text or parenthetical. Practical scenario, you quote a line at 2 minutes 14 seconds. You can write: (Channel Name 2:14) if the channel is your author, or (‚ÄúShortened Title‚Äù 2:14) if you are citing by title. Keep the timestamp format consistent, such as 2:14 or 01:02:14 for longer videos. If you are discussing multiple moments, put the timestamp in the sentence for clarity. For MLA guidance on in-text citations, see https://style.mla.org/in-text-citations/.

What if a YouTube video has no date, no author, or the title is weirdly formatted?

If the upload date is missing, use ‚Äún.d.‚Äù in the date position. If no clear author or uploader is available, start the Works Cited entry with the video title. If the title includes excessive capitalization, emojis, or promotional text, keep the wording but you may normalize capitalization to MLA title style. Do not rewrite the title into something new, but you can omit trailing clutter if it is not part of the actual title as displayed. Practical scenario, a short clip titled ‚ÄúYOU WONT BELIEVE THIS!!!‚Äù with no listed date. Your entry can begin with ‚ÄúYou Wont Believe This.‚Äù then YouTube, then the channel if available, then n.d., then the URL. If critical elements are missing, consider adding an access date. For examples, see https://style.mla.org/citing-online-videos/.

How do I cite a YouTube channel or a playlist instead of a single video in MLA 9?

To cite a channel, treat the channel page as the work. Use the channel name as the title of the page, then YouTube as the container, then the URL to the channel. If you are citing a playlist, use the playlist title in quotation marks, then YouTube, then the channel that created it, then the URL to the playlist. Practical scenario, you analyze how a creator organizes tutorials across a series. Citing the playlist helps readers find the full set, not just one video. If dates are available for playlists or channel pages, include the most relevant date shown, but many pages do not provide a clear publication date. In that case, include an access date if your instructor prefers it. For MLA‚Äôs container model and web page citations, see https://style.mla.org/works-cited-a-quick-guide/.

Do I need to include the full YouTube URL, and should I add the access date?

Include a direct URL that reliably leads to the content, usually the full https link. MLA allows you to omit ‚Äúhttps://‚Äù in some contexts, but many instructors prefer the full URL for clarity and easy access. Avoid shortened links if possible, since they can be less transparent. Access dates are optional in MLA 9, but they are useful when the content can change, be deleted, or be reuploaded. Practical scenario, you cite a news clip that might be taken down, or a live stream archive that could be edited. In those cases, add ‚ÄúAccessed Day Month Year.‚Äù at the end. If you are using a stable official upload, an access date is less necessary unless your instructor requests it. For MLA‚Äôs position on access dates and URLs, see https://style.mla.org/urls/.
